The Coolidge Cup, a national invitational speech and debate tournament sponsored by the Calvin Coolidge Presidential Foundation, also brought competitors to town for the weekend to compete for more than $15,000 in scholarship money. Coolidge served as the 30th president of the United States from 1923 to 1929, elevated from the vice presidency after Warren Harding died unexpectedly from a heart attack. Coolidge, a Republican, then won the 1924 election. The President Calvin Coolidge State Historic Site includes his boyhood home, the homes of relatives and family friends, his family’s cheese factory, and his father’s store, which was used as the Summer White House in 1924.

Virginia

Lynchburg: As American citizens celebrated freedom and liberty in their nation on Independence Day in 1961, a government founded on notions of the inalienable human rights to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness took action at a local level to deny those rights to their fellow citizens whose skin was not white. This little-taught chapter of local history is being brought to life in an original play, “Buried Deep,” produced through Endstation Theatre Company, affiliated with Randolph College. On that sweltering July day in Lynchburg, as many residents sought the relief offered by public pools, the city closed those pools down because some Black residents went to swim in the whites-only pools at Miller and Riverside parks. They were exercising their civil rights and making intentional strides toward integration and equality when many people were content to drag their feet despite a federal court’s recent ruling that mandated desegregation nationwide. Today, if one visits Riverside Park, an indentation in the ground where a pool once stood remains as a permanent scar of racial tensions in the not-so-distant past. “Buried Deep” is part of Endstation’s New Works initiative, a program that supports playwrights who create a script based on some aspect of Lynchburg-area history.

Washington

Everett: A nonprofit land trust has made its largest purchase ever to conserve 175 acres of forest and 3,500 feet of nearly pristine shoreline. Staff at the Whidbey Camano Land Trust said they knew they had to act quickly when a 226-acre beachfront property south of Coupeville came on the market last December. From the water, boaters may have seen the red house, old windmill, and cattle grazing atop the bluffs. The property near Keystone is home to one of the oldest farms on Whidbey Island. It also features a large forest and long stretch of beach. The site was at risk of being sold and developed into 22 high-end homes, according to the land trust. In late April, the land trust bought the property for $9.1 million, the most expensive purchase in the nonprofit’s nearly four-decade history. “We don’t get many opportunities to protect a chunk of habitat that size,” conservation director Ryan Elting told the Everett Herald. With the new property, called the Keystone Preserve, the trust will focus on habitat improvement and marine restoration. There are also plans to open public beach access as soon as 2024, as well as a trail network. The land trust has partnered with the Organic Farm School to manage the site. The nonprofit school on Whidbey Island will oversee the 50 acres of prairie and farm.

West Virginia

Charleston: Hershel W. “Woody” Williams, the last remaining Medal of Honor recipient from World War II, will lie in honor at the U.S. Capitol, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said Sunday. “Woody Williams embodied the best of America: living a life of duty, honor and courage,” Pelosi said in a joint statement. Schumer called Williams “an American hero who embodied the best of our country and the greatest generation.” Williams, who died Wednesday at 98, was a legend in his home state for his heroics under fire over several crucial hours at the battle for Iwo Jima. As a young Marine corporal, Williams went ahead of his unit in February 1945 and eliminated a series of Japanese machine gun positions. Facing small-arms fire, Williams fought for four hours, repeatedly returning to prepare demolition charges and obtain flamethrowers. Later that year, the 22-year-old Williams received the Medal of Honor from President Harry Truman. The Medal of Honor is the nation’s highest award for military valor. In remarks at a memorial Sunday in Charleston, U.S. Sen. Joe Manchin said Williams “never quit giving back.” That included raising money for gold star families – immediate family members of fallen service members – with an annual motorcycle ride. “It’s raised hundreds of thousands of dollars,” Manchin said. He joked that “it’s not going to be stopping, because Woody would come after me in a heartbeat.”

Wisconsin

Sheboygan: In four years, the city will lose its claim to having the world’s tallest free-flying American flag. The Acuity Insurance flagpole – the “World’s Tallest Symbol of Freedom” – stands 400 feet high. On July 4, 2026, the Flagpole of Freedom Park near Maine’s southeast coast is proposing to erect a flagpole larger than the Empire State Building. As the site is on a hill 315 feet tall, the 1,461-foot-high flagpole will reach 1,776 feet above sea level, which Flagpole of Freedom Park spokesperson Sarah Martin said pays homage to the year the United States declared independence. Although the Wisconsin flagpole will lose its distinction in the coming years, Acuity Communications Manager Paul Miller said it will still be a landmark. “The flagpole is one of the most visible landmarks on the Interstate 43 corridor and welcomes people to the Sheboygan community,” he said. “Many people stop to visit the flagpole, which is seen by drivers and passengers in over 50,000 vehicles that pass by our headquarters every day.” In addition to the flagpole, Acuity has a veterans memorial. There are 766 pavers with names of Sheboygan County residents who passed away serving in the line of duty in conflicts dating back to the Civil War. Miller said Acuity has no plans to increase the height of its flagpole because notching a record wasn’t the goal for building it.

Wyoming

Cheyenne: The U.S. Capitol insurrection dominated Thursday’s debate among U.S. Rep. Liz Cheney and her four Republican primary challengers, with Cheney pressing her Donald Trump-backed opponent on whether she agreed with the ex-president’s claim that widespread fraud cost him reelection. Harriet Hageman said there were “serious concerns” about the 2020 election but stopped short of repeating Trump’s false claim that drove thousands of his supporters to storm the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Even so, Hageman was dismissive of the U.S. House commission vice-chaired by Cheney that has been investigating the insurrection and events leading up to it. “They’re focusing on something that happened 18 months ago. They’re not focused on things that are important to the people of Wyoming,” said Hageman, a Cheyenne ranching and natural resources attorney. Republicans, she said, were being punished for “exercising their First Amendment rights” – a remark on which Cheney pounced as suggesting the insurrection was justified. Cheney’s role as one of just two Republicans on the Jan. 6 panel has stirred a backlash in deep-red Wyoming. The state GOP last year censured Cheney and voted to no longer recognize her as a Republican. “I will not violate my oath of office, and if you’re looking for someone who will, you need to vote for someone else on this stage,” she said during Thursday’s debate.

From USA TODAY Network and wire reports

search_result.title: In 2020, coronavirus impacted everything in Volusia-Flagler
search_result.text:
Pat Rice, Editor

The coronavirus pandemic started in China, quickly spread across the globe, and by March we knew that 2020 would be a year like no other.

COVID-19 impacted how we look. (Who thought the most ubiquitous clothing accessory of 2020 would be masks to cover our noses and mouths?)

It impacted how we greet each other, and how we say goodbye. (Would you like to fist bump or elbow bump?)

It financially impacted restaurants and retail stores and hotels and hair salons as people stopped traveling, dining out, and turned increasing to online shopping.

It impacted communication. Like many businesses, The News-Journal newsroom has been working remotely for months. Interaction between reporters and editors has been almost entirely via Zoom calls, cell phones, emails and texts.

Above all, COVID-19 impacted health. In Volusia and Flagler counties, the virus has claimed nearly 500 lives, and sickened thousands. Vaccines are finally arriving, but it will be months into 2021 before many of us can get a shot.

Throughout it all, The News-Journal's reporters and photographers have worked harder than ever to deliver the news, much of it tragic but some of it triumphant. Here are some of our reporters' takes on 2020, and how the coronavirus impacted the news.

Jim Abbott, Tourism

For Volusia County’s tourism industry, the impact of the coronavirus pandemic hit like a nuclear blast, from record-setting declines in hotel occupancy and bed-tax collections in April to lingering aftershocks that will continue into 2021.

In March, as public health officials advised people to avoid large gatherings that could spread the virus, the pandemic derailed two of the area’s marquee special events, Bike Week and spring break.

During Bike Week, Daytona Beach Mayor Derrick Henry ordered vendor permits pulled for the event’s final day in an effort to curb the virus’ spread. He took the unprecedented step of urged spring breakers not to come to the city amid the pandemic.

A month later, as the worldwide travel industry slowed to a pandemic-induced standstill, Volusia County tourism bed tax collections fell by a staggering 79.1% in April, by far the biggest decline on record. Average hotel occupancy for the month was down by 81% compared with 2019.

More:Volusia hotel occupancy, bed taxes plummet 80%

By summer, however, consistent weekend business powered by day-trippers seeking socially distanced beach getaways helped hoteliers rebound at a faster pace than other tourism-reliant counties in Central Florida.

In October, powered by a scaled-down edition of Biketoberfest, tourism bed-tax collections were down by about 5% year-over-year. That compared with a 23.9% year-over-year decline for the month in Brevard County and a whopping 69% drop in October collections in Orange County.

Yet there are still obstacles ahead in the coming year.

Convention and group travel business has yet to return, according to hoteliers, and the crucial influx of Canadian snowbirds has evaporated in the wake of COVID-related travel restrictions at the border.

Attendance will be limited at key events such as the Daytona 500 and the Rolex 24 At Daytona, and it’s unclear what effect the pandemic will have on Bike Week’s return in March.

With a vaccine on the way, there’s reason for optimism, said Bob Davis, president and CEO of the Lodging & Hospitality Association of Volusia County. Yet there are still challenges ahead, he said.

“We’re still coping with the virus, no doubt about it,” Davis said. “We’re praying that next year brings us some solace; that people will get their shots and tourism will come back. We’re working hard. We haven’t let up.”

Cassidy Alexander, Education

You don’t need me to tell you that 2020 has been a chaotic, dramatic, difficult and — there's really no other word for it — unprecedented year in education.

In February I wrote a series of stories about a group of high schoolers putting on a high school play. It was about the drama of the typical teenage experience. How could we have known that by the next month, the coronavirus pandemic would have stolen that typical experience and replaced it with an uncertain future?

More:Volusia parents bristle at graduation ceremony limits

I spent the rest of the year covering the temporary end of in-person learning, drive-thru graduations, a summer of waiting games with state leadership, the struggle to access information, the question of keeping everyone safe in schools that used to be considered havens, and the obvious disruption to the learning process.

It’s been hard for anyone — parents, students, teachers, administrators — to get a strong foothold, to get in front of things.

But I’ve been galvanized by another aspect of life this year that we may not have talked about enough: resilience. The feeling of walking into a classroom and finding that it is, in fact, still a classroom where students can learn. The sight of educators putting in the time to make things work for their students and families in less-than-ideal circumstances. The inexhaustible shared belief that we can do better.

So yes. It’s been a chaotic, dramatic, difficult, unprecedented year. That won’t stop when the calendars change to 2021. But it’s also been a year in which learning continued, against all the odds. And that’s something.

Abigail Brashear, Environment

This was an interesting year for a fledgling reporter like myself, who started her first full-time job at The News-Journal just before the pandemic hit.

As an environment, data and cities reporter, I cover everything from Ormond Beach’s City Commission meetings to septic tank pollution and beach erosion. In the first few months of the pandemic, I also spend time crunching coronavirus data.

The pandemic has dominated my coverage this year. I’ve covered how social distancing has affected beachgoers and protesting, and how only allowing essential workers to do their jobs changed air quality and manatee research.

The pandemic taught me the need for compassion in reporting. I wrote stories about DeLand families, already struggling from the pandemic whose homes were damaged when a tornado tore through the city. I covered a pride protest and spoke to people who were stuck at home with families who didn’t accept them. Giving a voice to the voiceless is part of our job, and it’s a job that I love.

The pandemic encouraged me to be more persistent as a reporter. Working from home threw everyone off for a while, but it forced me to expand the number of people I speak to regularly. I developed relationships based on the idea that the more people knew about the coronavirus, the better.

The pandemic also showed me the need to be a watchdog for our community. Once, I spent all night combing through and cleaning medical examiner data for a story about coronavirus deaths in of Florida.

More:Database: Florida's COVID-19 deaths

I’m tired. It’s been a long, long year. But covering endangered right whales, manatees and sea turtles always makes me smile. I love talking to the people who live in this community.

Even during a pandemic, Volusia and Flagler counties are passionate about the environment.

Frank Fernandez, Courts and Palm Coast

Covering courts in the time of coronavirus saw the drama of the courtroom diced up into boxes on a computer screen.

You “Zoomed” into and out of hearings. You watched as defendants sometimes appeared in court. But often the accused would appear in their own little box on a computer screen while they themselves sat in the larger box that was the Volusia County jail.

If they weren’t in jail, defendants appeared from wherever they happened to be: an apartment, a workplace or from their cars, sometimes driving around to find a sweet spot for cellphone reception.

Going to a courthouse meant getting your temperature taken as you walked in the door and answering the now-familiar virus-related questions.

I also spent some of 2020 covering Palm Coast, where City Hall and elections provided plenty of controversy.

Palm Coast Mayor Milissa Holland was the subject of an ethics complaint by the city’s former compliance manager, Jay Maher, who said Holland violated the city charter to benefit her employer, Coastal Cloud. The complaint is pending, and Holland has denied any wrongdoing.

More:Complaints detail accusations against Palm Coast mayor

Maher retired but that didn’t stop the city from firing him retroactively in September. That meant Maher had both resigned and been fired, making him unique among a list of high-level employees who were either fired or resigned since the arrival of City Manager Matt Morton in 2019.

Holland, with the help of out-of-town money, beat back a challenge from Alan Lowe to win a second term.

Mark Harper, Politics

Early in 2020, before the pandemic, it was obvious we were heading into a maelstrom of an election year. President Donald Trump was being impeached — remember that? — the Democratic field of presidential candidates remained wide open and people on all sides, it seemed, were angry.

In January, I rang up some life coaches. One suggested revisiting The Serenity Prayer on a regular basis: “Lord, grant me the serenity to accept the things I can not change, the courage to change the things I can and the wisdom to know the difference.”

I can only wish serenity, courage and wisdom weren’t in such short supply in 2020.

The pandemic exposed our fractures and gave rise to another virus: misinformation and disinformation. Intentional or not, it is clear a large portion of the electorate seems either incapable of or unwilling to distinguish fact from fiction. And many so-called leaders fully capable of grasping facts are embedding themselves into the fiction for their own self-interest.

More:Politics stressing you out? Here’s how to cope in 2020

Depending on where you sit, the presidential election is now either six weeks over or not yet done. Where I sit, in reality, the election is over. Joe Biden won. Donald Trump lost. This is not a matter of opinion but a matter of fact. Biden won more votes. He won the Electoral College.

Bold claims about widespread voter fraud were sizzle without steak.

And case by case, death by death, the pandemic has proven itself a true tragedy.

Lord, grant me the serenity …

Eileen Zaffiro-Kean, Daytona Beach

One of Daytona Beach's biggest stories of 2020 was unquestionably the explosion of development taking place between the Halifax River and Ridgewood Avenue.

The new $65 million, 11-story Brown & Brown headquarters building overlooking the river is about to start welcoming new employees. Riverfront Park is in the middle of a $23 million reinvention hoped to be complete late next year.

A Tampa-based developer is moving forward with plans to build 200 new apartments and a 500-space parking garage on a vacant property at the corner of International Speedway Boulevard and Ridgewood Avenue.

More:Downtown Daytona Beach getting new apartments, parking garage

The city just completed a $4 million reconfiguration and revitalization of Beach Street between Orange Avenue and Bay Street. And Burgoyne Properties is hoping to get final approval from city commissioners in early next 2021 to move forward with plans to build multi-family housing, a parking garage, hotel, office space, shops and restaurants on its property fronting Beach Street between International Speedway Boulevard and Bay Street.

The COVID-19 pandemic made covering city of Daytona Beach stories more of a challenge. But I was always able to figure out a way to get the information I needed. Google, websites, social media, Zoom, live streaming, emails, texts and cell phones are wonderful tools for pandemic-era reporters.

The best way to get the most detail and information for most stories is to see and hear things in person. But looking back, I don't think much of what I normally do was compromised. I was able to watch most meetings either online or on a government TV channel. I did most interviews over the phone, and I don't think that hampered the vast majority of conversations. And I still drove to places I wrote about, and talked to people in relatively safe outdoor situations.

Clayton Park, Business

My top story of 2020: How the coronavirus pandemic sped up rather than slowed growth on Daytona’s LPGA corridor

When the coronavirus pandemic caused the local economy to lurch to an abrupt halt in March, I thought Daytona Beach’s LPGA Boulevard would wind up stuck with a bunch of stalled half-built projects.

Wrong.

The east-west corridor had been the region’s epicenter for growth and development in recent years. The LPGA’s area’s new developments include the Latitude Margaritaville 55-and-older community, thee ICI Homes all-ages Mosaic communities, the side-by-side Tanger Outlets and Tomoka Town Center shopping centers, and a slew of new luxury apartments.

The COVID-19 crisis only served to speed up that area’s growth.

Latitude Margaritaville community saw the completion of more than 400 homes in both 2018 and 2019. That number is expected to hit or come close to reaching 500 in 2020, according to developer Bill Bullock of Minto Communities.

The reason: an increase in newcomers leaving more densely populated urban areas in the Northeast and upper Midwest.

More:Margaritaville is biggest beneficiary of Daytona's building permit fee waiver

But Minto was far from being the only one to accelerate construction activity in the LPGA area this year.

North American Development Group, the developer of Tomoka Town Center, completed two new retail buildings and is proceeding with plans to further develop the shopping center in 2021.

Another developer, Orlando-based Unicorp began constructing a new shopping center across the street called Shoppes at Williamson Crossing that is expected to welcome several new restaurants and shops in the new year.

And an Ohio developer recently won a federal contract to begin building a new Veteran’s Affairs outpatient center next to Daytona State College’s Advanced Technology College.

Meanwhile, Orlando developer Beat Kahli is proceeding with plans to break ground in 2021 on a mixed-use development called Avalon Park Daytona Beach that could bring as many as 10,000 new homes and 1 million square feet of retail and office space. The project will cover 3,000 acres stretching from Latitude Margaritaville north to State Road 40/West Granada Boulevard.

And set to open in the first quarter of 2021, along the northeast side of the Interstate 95/LPGA interchange, will be a supersized Buc-ee’s that will become the largest gas station in Florida with 120 fuel pumps.

All this growth is increasing concerns about traffic congestion along LPGA and other roads in the area. A new group called the LPGA Coalition has been formed to study possible solutions and how to fund them.

Developers have stepped up construction activity because they are betting that the demand will be stronger than ever for new homes, shops and restaurants in the LPGA area when the pandemic finally comes to an end.

Nikki Ross, Health

At the start of 2020, I thought I was going to complete large projects on the impact of Florida’s Baker Act on children, and the frequency of hospital transfers in Volusia and Flagler counties.

Instead, I was thrust into daily, round the clock coverage of the coronavirus pandemic. It has been an onslaught of stories about death, hospitalizations and rising cases.

I write The News-Journal's daily coronavirus update. I also keep up with ever-evolving information about the virus, it’s spread and the COVID-19 vaccine. Seemingly every story I write now has some element of the virus, including stories about Flagler County Government, which I also cover.

One of the most memorable stories I wrote was back in March, about an Ormond Beach resident hospitalized with coronavirus. She told me that the country was not prepared for what the virus would do to people. She was right.

More:Coronavirus-positive Volusia resident: ‘This country is not prepared’

That woman was the first person with coronavirus I ever interviewed, but not the last. I still think about her and her journey today. Thankfully, she recovered.

Another story that sticks out in my mind is that of 26-year-old Emily Murkerson, who died at Halifax Health after she was hit by a car in Daytona Beach. Because of coronavirus, her family wasn’t allowed to see her while she was hospitalized and after her death, her parents blamed the hospital for not letting them sit with her. That was in April, when hospital restrictions were the norm nationwide.

In a normal year, a girl being hit by a car and dying in a local hospital wouldn’t have been major news. It might have been written up as a brief, if that. But because of the coronavirus pandemic, and the circumstances surrounding her stay at the hospital, it became national news.

The virus isn’t going away any time soon. My hope for 2021 is that the stories will become positive with the introduction of the vaccine and as health experts understand the nature of the virus.

Victoria Villavueva-Marquez, Social Services

The coronavirus pandemic worsened problems for many of those who had already fallen on hard times.

Some faced heightened levels of anxiety and depression. Others lost their lives to addiction. But while the pandemic caused tragedy, there were many heroic efforts to answer the call for help.

For a mother of four whose newborn arrived on Easter, fear set in moments after the infant took his first breaths. Jessica Johnson, 33, wondered whether the nurses who entered her room at Halifax Health Medical Center in Daytona Beach had come in contact with someone who had contracted the coronavirus. She worried that she would not be able to protect her newborn son from potential infection.

More:Amid coronavirus, new mothers fear for their babies

The good news was that her baby was fine. But COVID-19 caused immense stress for pregnant women and new mothers, which posed a serious threat to their health. One expert told me that anxiety releases a hormone called cortisol that can contribute to pre-term labor.

As Volusia County sank deeper into the pandemic, it became evident that the crisis had taken a serious toll on the mental health of many across the area. One mental health organization that has been around for more than 10 years provided a record number of therapy sessions in October.

Drug abuse also increased in Volusia and Flagler counties. The area's drug crisis existed long before coronavirus, but with it came a corresponding increase in drug deaths and nonfatal overdoses.

In September, the Volusia Recovery Alliance led law enforcement leaders and addiction advocates in a Zoom call, where the meeting participants came up with ideas to decrease drug overdoses.

The Alliance to put out a call for volunteers with lived experience who could respond to the scenes of drug overdoses with Volusia County sheriff’s deputies. The organization also started passing out the overdose-reversal medication naloxone and other harm reduction supplies to drug users across the county.

And as the pandemic put thousands of people in the region out of work, there was an unparalleled demand for food.

The Council on Aging of Volusia County was among several organizations that delivered meals to the doorsteps of older adults who were confined to their homes.

In July, the number of clients who received meals through the Meals on Wheels program climbed from 326 to more than 600. Meanwhile, the number of volunteers who delivered those meals dropped from 220 to 150. But the smaller number of volunteers made sure everyone was fed.

Numerous other groups also stepped up too provide food and other essentials to those in need. Even nine months into the ongoing crisis, help remains available.

Ken Willis, Sports

Thinking back to the pandemic’s effects on the local sports scene, I think about our biggest and oldest franchises — NASCAR and the Daytona Tortugas — as well as some rare industries that didn’t just survive the shutdowns and slowdowns, but sometimes thrived.

• The 2020 Daytona 500 was run roughly a month before the world shut down, but when recalling the usual scene from that day — particularly the throngs of humanity milling about during pre-race festivities — it seems like decades ago.

More:Ryan Newman’s Daytona 500 wreck reminds us of racing’s danger | KEN WILLIS

As March turned into April, a lot of plans were worked and reworked inside the glass building on Speedway Boulevard, and eventually NASCAR found a way to crank the engines and bring back live competition to televisions across the land.

The revamped schedule included two gap-filling events at Daytona International Speedway — a sports-car race in July and the debut of the Speedway’s road course for NASCAR, in August.

• The Tortugas were prepared for a year-long celebration of the 100th anniversary of professional baseball on City Island. But it was going to be cloaked in dread, since the Tortugas were rumored to be among the teams on the chopping block as Major League Baseball planned to reduce the minor leagues by about 25% of its teams.

Bad news: There would be no 100th anniversary season because the minor leagues were shut down. Good news: There would be a 101st anniversary season, because in the end, the Tortugas made the cut.

• When golf was deemed a safe activity, with certain restrictions, most local courses were able to continue paying the bills. Some even saw an uptick in summertime numbers during a time of year when local play usually slows down dramatically.

• Did you see the boat ramps and fishing piers over the summer and early fall? It seems a lot of locals came to realize just how much water we have around here. The result was a run on live bait and the emptying of inventory at area boat dealerships.

And you probably know what that means. Assuming things return to normal sometime in 2021, expect to see a lot of "slightly used" boats for sale by summer.

Zach Dean, Sports

Normally, the sports world never takes time off. There’s always a game on.

But then the coronavirus brought the country to its knees back in March, and the dominos started to fall.

First it was the NBA. Then March Madness. Then spring training. Then NASCAR.

For years, all I’d done was write about sports. The pandemic changed that.

I remember calling Bethune-Cookman head basketball coach Ryan Ridder the day after the Wildcats’ MEAC tournament was canceled. Before starting the interview, he said “Wait. Zach. What exactly are you going to do now?”

I had no clue. Nine months later (how is that possible?!), I’m still not sure how I got through those few months, but I’m glad I went through it.

I helped, a lot, on the news-side, writing stories about toilet paper shortages (yep), beach openings, and closings, and reopenings, COVID survivors, and outdoor churches. Did I love it? No. Did I miss sports? You have no idea. But I think I grew as a writer because of it.

More:After 8 weeks, Ormond coronavirus survivor returns home with “second chance” at life

More:Coronavirus: Volusia shoppers endure long lines, morning mayhem

Sports eventually returned. First it was NASCAR, then golf, then MLB, NBA, NHL, college football and the NFL. We had football back Thursday-thru-Monday every week this past fall, and it was glorious. I want to thank everyone who made it possible.

I learned a lot about myself when the sports world stopped. I’m glad I did. Now please, don’t ever, ever do that again.

Chris Boyle, Sports

Rarely this year — this seemingly endless, occasionally hopeless year — have I felt uplifted. But two instances come to mind — a pair of stories I wrote in the last couple weeks of October.

"Overcoming adversity" is an oft-used cliche in high school sports, the beat I have covered since 2013. But two teenagers — Flagler Palm Coast junior football player Jayden Wilkinson and Seabreeze cheerleader/basketball player Julia Bosset — truly experienced adversity, head-on.

More:FPC junior lineman Jayden Wilkinson upbeat in battle with rare form of leukemia

In the weeks leading up to fall football season, after getting the green light to play in spite of the ongoing pandemic, Wilkinson became sick and later learned he had acute myeloid leukemia. He's undergone three rounds of chemotherapy along and four lumbar punctures, and he's due for a bone marrow transplant in the opening week of 2021. Julie Diaz, Wilkinson's mother, told me just before Thanksgiving her son is "kicking butt."

More:FOR JULIA: Matt Bosset, Seabreeze dedicate football win to his sister after cardiac arrest

Bosset, meanwhile, collapsed onto the court during her team's first conditioning session and went into cardiac arrest. School resource officer Iriabeth Lee, administered CPR, which proved pivotal in saving her life. A week later, Julia returned home to celebrate her brother Matt's 18th birthday with her parents and the family's beloved dog, Bosston. She cheered Matt and the rest of the Sandcrabs' football players on from the sidelines when they squared off with rival Mainland on Oct. 30.

It warms my heart to pen a happy ending. Boy, did we need a few of them in 2020.

Patricio Balona, Justice

The pandemic, unfortunately, did not curtail crime in Volusia and Flagler counties in 2020.

“The (reporting party) is saying a female was stabbed in the face inside the City Island Library,” dispatchers relayed to police over the scanner on the morning of Sept. 15.

As a longtime Crimes/Public Safety reporter, it is not unusual to hear people being hurt. But the story of a 63-year-old library assistant attacked by a homeless man with a pair of scissors at the Daytona Beach Regional Library at City Island, stands out as the most memorable crime story of the year.

More:Police: Employee attacked with scissors inside Daytona Beach library; suspect is in custody

Police and first responders rushed to the scene of the scissors attack and reported finding the victim, Kaia Simonson, bleeding heavily from the face and in and out of consciousness. Former Police Chief Craig Capri would later say Simonson suffered a broken nose and stab wounds to one of her eyes. The attack led to the immediate closure of the library, prompted increased police patrols in the area and Volusia County officials added a second security guard at the building.

Since the coronavirus pandemic, I have mostly been working from home. That places me an hour away from Daytona Beach, so I rely on scanner traffic and sources who have come to trust me as a reporter to keep up with breaking news.

I quickly Tweeted the breaking news of the scissors attack and filed a short story. Shortly after, I got a call from then Deputy Chief Jakari Young, who is now the Daytona Beach police Chief. He confirmed all the information I had gathered including the nature of the attack, the name of the suspect and that Simonson was taken to Halifax Health Medical Center.

Crime, of course, never stops.

In November, a wave of shootings rocked Daytona Beach in a six-day period. Four people were killed and five others were wounded by gunfire between Nov. 23 and Nov. 30. Three of the fatal shootings involved men quarreling over women. A fourth case was a killing during a game of cards, according to Daytona Beach police.

Katie Kustura, West Volusia

It’s been nearly a year since Jane Shang resigned as city manager of Deltona, and the city is still lacking a permanent manager.

Motions to terminate Shang, who served as the manager for four and a half years, had been made at a few different points during her last couple of years with the city. The one that nearly led to her ousting was made by Mayor Heidi Herzberg. The City Commission 4--3 vote on Jan. 21, 2020, wasn’t enough to fire Shang, as a super majority is required.

But the commission followed up with a 4-3 vote of no confidence. Shang resigned soon thereafter. The commission voted unanimously the following week to accept Shang’s resignation and to move Marc-Antonie Cooper from deputy city manager to interim city manager.

More:Jane Shang resigns as Deltona's city manager

Severance pay and accrued leave for Shang carried a price tag of $286,881.

Cooper held the helm until Nov. 19 when the commission voted 4-3 to have him return to the role of deputy city manager and then voted 6-1 to offer John Peters III, who was serving as the public works director, the role of interim manager.

One noticeable change since Peters was promoted: Plexiglass dividers between the commissioners on the dais, and additional socially-distanced seating for residents on the floor of the commission’s chambers.

Other cities in West Volusia have taken similar measures due to the coronavirus pandemic. DeBary, DeLand, Lake Helen and Orange City also set up socially-distanced seating for meeting attendees. DeLand and Orange City’s representatives passed mandates requiring face coverings indoors, and DeBary, Deltona and Lake Helen approved resolutions encouraging the wearing of masks to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

Erica Van Buren, Flagler County

The year that was 2020 brought on a number of challenges.

The “Flagler Beach dune project could be in jeopardy”, reads the headline of the first story published in June that led me to become the self-proclaimed “Dune Queen.”

I had no idea that six stories later the dune project would still be underway. The Flagler Beach community shared mixed feelings about the $17 million project, which is fully funded with federal and state dollars.

The purpose of the 2.6-mile project requires property owners with parcels east of State Road A1A from South 6th Street to South 28th Street, to grant easements to the federal, state and local agencies involved so they can add sand and natural vegetation to dunes that protect the road from the Atlantic Ocean. A1A has washed out during two recent hurricanes.

However, a number of residents refuse to sign the easement, which has caused the project to be delayed a number of times.

More:Flagler County commissioners approve eminent domain for dune restoration project

In August, a resident started a crowdfunding campaign to rally everyone together. The purpose was to convince the homeowners holding out to get on board with the project. As of Dec. 22 the GoFundMe page has raised $49,000. The money raised is designated for the homeowners currently holding out.

Tackling such a story in the midst of a pandemic has made connecting with city officials and other potential sources a bit challenging. Pre-pandemic, it was easy to catch a council member or commissioner after a meeting to get answers to follow up questions. But speaking with city officials was especially difficult when meetings were held virtually.

Now that the meetings are hybrid, virtual and in person connecting is a bit easier. Still, taking the proper precautions to guard against catching the coronavirus is still a reality. Wearing facial coverings, making sure to keep a safe distance, fighting the urge to reach out and shake someone’s hand at the beginning of an introduction, adds an additional layer of challenges.

As a journalist, my job is to give a voice to the voiceless during these unprecedented times. I must remain unbiased, even though the loss we’ve experienced as a nation affected me personally. I lost my mother to the coronavirus earlier this year.

That adds another challenge. How can I speak for the voiceless when my own voice is muffled?

search_result.title: Photos: Russia invades Ukraine | CNN
search_result.text:
Cars burn after a Russian military strike in central Kyiv, Ukraine, on October 10. At least 19 people were killed and more than 100 injured in Russian missile strikes on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities on Monday as Moscow targeted critical energy infrastructure.

After months of military buildup and brinkmanship, Russia launched an unprecedented assault on Ukraine in late February.

Explosions rang through a number of Ukrainian cities, including the capital Kyiv, in a broad invasion that began before dawn on February 24.

But 100 days later, the invasion has not been the military success Moscow hoped. The bulk of fighting has now moved to the east after failed Russian advances in central Ukraine.

Meanwhile, millions of refugees have fled Ukraine to neighboring countries.

The United States, the European Union and other Western allies have been rolling out sanctions in response to Russia's actions. Many people around the world have also been rallying in support of Ukraine.

Russia had been tightening its military grip around Ukraine since last year, amassing tens of thousands of soldiers, as well as equipment and artillery, on its neighbor's doorstep. The escalation in the years-long conflict has triggered the greatest security crisis in Europe since the Cold War, and it has also sparked an intense showdown between Western powers and Moscow.

Editor's note: This gallery contains graphic images. Viewer discretion is advised.

search_result.title: Super Bowl 2023 comes to dramatic end after Rihanna, celeb ...
search_result.text:
Arizona Republic

Arizona felt a little like the center of the universe as professional athletes, celebrities and football fans converged on metro Phoenix for the 2023 Super Bowl at State Farm Stadium.

An array of star-studded Super Bowl-themed events took place in the lead-up to the Philadelphia Eagles and Kansas City Chiefs' showdown in Glendale. That's not to mention Rihanna's halftime show or the pregame performances from Chris Stapleton, Babyface and Sheryl Lee Ralph.

Here's a recap of celebrity sightings, fan events, autograph signings, concerts, parties — all the biggest moments before, and during, the big game.

Super Bowl in Arizona 2023: Updates on traffic, weather, restrictions

Travis Kelce is ready to party after the trophy ceremony

Well done, whoever plays music over the public-address system at State Farm Stadium.

Literally.

During the trophy ceremony immediately following the thrilling game, in which the Kansas City Chiefs beat the Philadelphia Eagles 38-35 with a field goal in the final seconds, Travis Kelce did what he does from the on-field stage: Screamed, "You gotta fight! For your right!"

And then he let the Chiefs fans finish, "TO PARRRRRRTTTTY!"

Which they did, screaming with delight. And immediately the stadium speakers blasted "Fight for Your Right" by the Beastie Boys.

Rock on.

Super Bowl 57 comes to a dramatic end

The tension inside State Farm Stadium was incredible — as was the noise.

No surprise, since these are two of the loudest fan bases in the NFL. They went back and forth through the second half till Kansas City kicked a field goal with 11 seconds left to go up 38-35.

It was a wild end to a wild day. Which made it kind of perfect.

— Bill Goodykoontz

Pregnant and stunning in red: Rihanna crushed the Super Bowl 2023 halftime show

After party: 7 Westgate restaurant and bars offer late hours on Super Bowl Sunday

Whether you celebrating your team's win or looking for a pick-me-up if they didn't, you won't need to go far for a post-game drink.

Seven restaurants and bars near the stadium at Westgate Entertainment District are staying open late after the game. Karaoke, check; food, check; drinks, check; pool, check.

Here are seven restaurants and bars with extended hours on game day.

— Bahar Anooshahr

After a powerhouse Super Bowl performance, everyone wants to know: Is Rihanna pregnant again?

At around 6:28 p.m. on Sunday, Feb. 12, the yearslong Rihanna drought came to an end.

Amid the excitement surrounding hearing her perform classics like "Umbrella,” there was rampant speculation on social media about whether Rihanna is pregnant again nine months after giving birth to her first son. Some posts were more tactful than others.

The NFL shared footage of A$AP Rocky enjoying Rihanna’s performance and some millennials drew parallels between Rihanna’s backup dancers’ outfits and the 2008 Disney film ‘Minutemen.’

A representative for Rihanna confirmed that she is indeed expecting her next child, making her Super Bowl performance possibly the biggest pregnancy reveal ever.

— KiMi Robinson

Rihanna reasserts her pop music dominance at her halftime show

We’ve all been wondering who Rihanna might bring out to join her in the spotlight when she took the world’s biggest stage at State Farm Stadium for the Super Bowl 2023 halftime show and … surprise.

She got along just fine without a single cameo.

Rihanna made her entrance on a floating platform high above the field, rocking a stylish red jumpsuit and matching latex bustier singing “Bitch Better Have My Money,” seamlessly working her way through a dizzying celebration of her catalog that put the focus squarely on her most iconic hits, from “Umbrella” to “Work.”

She hasn’t toured since late 2016 and this halftime show more than lived up to the promise of a world-class performer reasserting her place in the pop music stratosphere.

— Ed Masley

Rihanna's Super Bowl 2023 playlist: Here's every song from her halftime show performance

One fan paid over $30K for her seat. Was it worth it?

Liz Foster had the best seat in the house for Super Bowl 57, between the Philadelphia Eagles and Kansas City Chiefs.

And she’s a Cincinnati Bengals fan. She and her husband Bill bought the tickets before the AFC Championship, in which the Chiefs beat Cincinnati.

“We were just hoping the Bengals would be here so we planned ahead,” Foster said. “We were putting out good vibes.”

They were also putting out good money — Foster wouldn’t come clean on exactly how much they spent, but she hinted at it — “30-ish,” she said.

As in $30,000?

“Plus some.”

Plus how much? Foster wasn’t saying. But even without her favorite team playing in the game, she said a backup plan:

“I’m here for Rihanna.”

— Bill Goodykoontz

Fan zone:The best seat at Super Bowl 2023 cost her $30,000 (plus some). And she's a Bengals fan

Fans at the Hance Park watch party aren't just blown away by Rihanna

It's getting a bit rough in downtown Phoenix for us mere mortals who didn't make it inside State Farm Stadium in Glendale.

The winds are whipping around Margaret T. Hance Park, where the official NFL watch party is underway at the Super Bowl Experience. According to the National Weather Service, the wind is blowing west at more than 20 mph, kicking up dead grass and the few leaves left on the trees.

That hasn't tamped down the excitement at the park, where it's been difficult — if at all possible — to navigate from one side to the other because the crowd in front of the stage is just that dense.

— KiMi Robinson

Are you ready for Rihanna?

The Super Bowl has rarely had a more anticipated halftime show.

Rihanna, one of the most successful pop sensations of the century, is making her return to live performance for the first time since 2018, when she did the Grammys. It's been even longer since she’s toured.

We spoke to several members of the team that helped her put this show together and they promised us "It's nothing like you've ever seen before.” Her music director added, “Trust me, this is my fourth Super Bowl halftime. And I must say, Rihanna has pushed the bar."

The singer herself is promising a “jam-packed ... celebration of my catalog in the best way that we could have put it together."

— Ed Masley

Adele at State Farm Stadium for the Super Bowl: 'I'm going just for Rihanna'

Adele is cheering for Team Rihanna at Super Bowl 2023 in Glendale, just like she promised.

The British singer — who can always be counted on for a good reaction meme — was spotted in a box at State Farm Stadium on Sunday. Just over a week earlier, she told the crowd at one of her Las Vegas residency shows that she's "going just for Rihanna."

Hopefully there will be some cameras pointed her way during the halftime show performance.

— KiMi Robinson

Chris Stapleton spared us the all-too-common national anthem showboating

Is Chris Stapleton “only the best voice in the world,” as Babyface suggested at a press conference in downtown Phoenix Thursday morning?

To be fair, few singers could hope to live up to that level of hype. But Stapleton does have a wonderful voice, as anyone at all familiar with the Grammy-winning country singer’s catalog would surely testify.

And he used it to brilliant effect at State Farm Stadium without making it feel like he was out there to impress us with a show of vocal pyrotechnics.

It was more about the song itself, which as Stapleton said, can go horribly wrong. But this one didn’t.

— Ed Masley

Review:Chris Stapleton's deeply soulful Super Bowl national anthem, plus Sheryl Lee Ralph, Babyface

Sheryl Lee Ralph delivers a monumental ‘Lift Every Voice and Sing’

Sheryl Lee Ralph, the Emmy-winning star of “Abbott Elementary,” got the pregame entertainment off to a breathtaking start with her version of “Lift Every Voice and Sing,” the Black national anthem, looking powerful in a flowing, off-the-shoulder red gown and matching gloves.

At Thursday’s pregame press conference in Phoenix, Ralph said her goal was “to make sure we could have a version for people to understand the great lyrics of this song and what it means.”

And that’s exactly how it went, a life-affirming testament to the deep meaning of the lyrics, well served by Ralph’s Broadway experience. If you didn’t understand those lyrics, you weren’t listening. — Ed Masley

Here's what to expect in 2023:How long does the Super Bowl national anthem take?

How to watch Chris Stapleton sing the national anthem at Super Bowl 2023

Country superstar Chris Stapleton will sing the national anthem just before Super Bowl 2023 kicks off at 4:30 p.m. Sunday at State Farm Stadium.

He’ll be joined in the pregame ceremonies by Babyface, who will sing “America the Beautiful,” and Sheryl Lee Ralph, of “Abbot Elementary,” who will sing “Lift Every Voice and Sing.”

Each song will be performed in American Sign Language as well, by Arizona native Troy Kotsur, who won a Best Supporting Actor Oscar for “Coda”; Colin Denny, a member of the Navajo Nation in Arizona; and Justina Miles.

Here’s everything to know about today’s national anthem, including how long it might last.

— Jill Cassidy

Super Bowl pregame: Sheryl Crow soaks up the sun, suggests new footwear for Patrick Mahomes

Sheryl Crow was midway through a hit-filled concert at the On Location tailgate party outside State Farm Stadium when she took a moment to reflect on her footwear — spectacular studded black open-toed clogs with heels that had to be at least 4 inches high.

“All I’m saying,” she said, “is I think Patrick Mahomes should have to run in these shoes.”

That would definitely be a game changer.

Crow and her band took the stage to a raucous recording of the Rolling Stones’ “Start Me Up” — a bold move, to be sure, and a handy frame of reference for the brand of rock ‘n’ roll that has underscored her finest hours from the start.
